Why not go further Jo, why not wish the price of public motorised transport go so high that we be forced to revert to horse and buggy, is there simply something aesthetically appealing to you about a communal mode of transportation?
 
 Oil is not simply fuel, the wide variety of uses it has, ie plastics, mean an exceptionally expensive oil supply would make everything more expensive. It's very much debatable if under such a situation the poor would be able to afford food, let alone a tram fare. Is this a price you are willing to pay?
 
 Comrade, in Communism there is money, projects are bought in human lives.
Jo Bennett

The vast majority of fossil fuels are used to produce energy. True there are other uses as well, but they use a relatively small quantity. If fuel can be replaced for the most part with renewables then it will reduce demand for oil, lowering the price for less wasteful uses. Fossil fuel use for burning should be kept artificially high after this, assuming advances in technology don't reduce the cost of renewables substantially, which it seems likely they will.
 
 As for vegetable oil, I was being facetious, but it is well known that some diesel engines run fine off vegetable oil, the problem is that is could never be produced in sufficient quantity to meet current demands for fuel. It's debatable whether it could meet to fuel demands of remote areas. I have no objection to private transport, it's just that until we have a renewable means of powering it, it is advisable to strike the balance more in favour of the environment than at present. I'm not sure the vast amount of horses, plus oats etc. would be viable as alternative transport.
Symbiote

Undoubtedly the development of efficient alternatives to fossil fuels would be a desirable outcome.
 
 The whole "I hope the price of fuel goes high so that there will be less demand for fuel so that fuel will be cheaper" thing doesn't work though. If anything, it may be the plastics that disappear first and the fuel last.
 
 The system of supply and demand allocates given quantities of resources as efficiently over time as it does over space, provided full privatisation exists, which it obviously does not at present, and is exceptionally unlikely to be in future. What you would expect is a steadily rising oil price until a replacement was found, with the actual supply of oil never running dry (at some sufficiently high price point, alternatives to oil will be more economic).
 
 Interestingly, a well regarded scientist at the moment is putting forward the theory that so-called "fossil fuels" are not the decaying remnants of ancient animals at all, but are actually constantly generated in the earth's core, periodically rising to the crust. In which case they would be "renewable", though at what rate I am unsure.
Jo Bennett
